title: Roman sun hat: A 'very rare' 1,600-year-old brimmed cap that may have protected a Roman soldier from Egyptian sandstorms
summary: A rare example of a sun hat from late Roman Egypt that was stitched together from fabrics in five colors.

title: Time may be a psychological projection, philosopher argues
summary: Is time real, or an illusion? The best answer may be neither: Both physics and philosophy suggest that time is a projection of the mind onto a timeless reality.

title: Antarctica's Southern Ocean might be gearing up for a thermal 'burp' that could last a century
summary: When humans manage to cut enough emissions and eventually reduce global temperatures, new research shows the Southern Ocean could kick warming back into gear.

title: Scientists mapped the shape of a supernova for the first time ever – and it's not what we expected: Space photo of the week
summary: Astronomers using data from the Very Large Telescope (VLT) have revealed that the initial "breakout" phase of a supernova is elongated, not perfectly spherical.

title: Are biodegradable plastics really worth the hype?
summary: Plastic pollution is poisoning the planet. Some experts suggest making plastics from more "natural" materials, but research shows those still have risks.

title: Climate change is real. It's happening. And it's time to make it personal.
summary: We found the psychological impetus people need to take action on climate change — realizing it will affect them and their way of life personally.

title: Are humans still evolving? An anthropologist breaks it down.
summary: We are indeed still evolving, though it can be hard to tell because it happens over generations and often involves things you can't see, such as what foods different people are able to digest.

title: Science history: Astronomy graduate student Jocelyn Bell Burnell discovers a signal of 'little green men,' but her adviser gets the Nobel Prize — Nov. 28, 1967
summary: Astronomer Jocelyn Bell Burnell detected a strange signal from outer space that would lead to the discovery of the radio pulsar. The signal, once described as coming from "little green men," would earn her adviser the Nobel Prize in physics in 1974.

title: How dangerous are interstellar objects like 3I/ATLAS?
summary: Interstellar objects like 3I/ATLAS are most likely to enter our solar system from two specific directions, a new study suggests. What does it mean for Earth?

title: 100,000 mph 'comet fragment' explodes in green fireball over Great Lakes, eerie videos show
summary: A fireball lit up the skies over the Great Lakes in the early hours of Sunday and was visible for hundreds of miles.

title: People in China lived alongside 'chicken-killing tigers' long before domestic cats arrived
summary: Leopard cats were living alongside people in ancient China for more than 3,500 years before domestic cats arrived from Europe via the Silk Road.

title: Can't decide between a telescope and binoculars? Read this before Black Friday
summary: We break down the key differences to help you make an informed choice before the sales hit, so you don't waste money on something you won't use.

title: Decades-long droughts doomed one of the world's oldest civilizations
summary: A series of lengthy droughts brought about the fall of the Indus Valley Civilization, a new study finds.

title: Archaeology Fragments Quiz: Can you work out what these mysterious artifacts are?
summary: Break out your best magnifying glass to solve these visual archaeology puzzles.

title: A structured system: the secrets of Germany’s scientific reputation
summary:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03778-y

The European country has long been recognized as a model of efficiency and innovation — here’s how its research ecosystem is organized.
body: Nature, Published online: 27 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03778-y The European country has long been recognized as a model of efficiency and innovation — here’s how its research ecosystem is organized.

title: Ancient DNA offers clues about mysterious prehistoric settlement in China
summary:
Nature, Published online: 26 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03593-5

Using genomic data, researchers have uncovered the origins and cultural practices of the people of Shimao, a 4,000-year-old fortified settlement in north…
body: Nature, Published online: 26 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03593-5 Using genomic data, researchers have uncovered the origins and cultural practices of the people of Shimao, a 4,000-year-old fortified settlement in northern China.

title: ADHD diagnoses are growing. What’s going on?
summary:
Nature, Published online: 26 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03855-2

More children and adults are being diagnosed with ADHD in some countries. Science is helping to understand why — and how best to provide support.
body: Nature, Published online: 26 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03855-2 More children and adults are being diagnosed with ADHD in some countries. Science is helping to understand why — and how best to provide support.

title: What happened at COP30? 4 science take-homes from the climate summit
summary:
Nature, Published online: 25 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03802-1

COP30 negotiated efforts to protect forests and ramp up financial packages for climate action, but with one glaring omission: a road map to cut fossil fu…
body: Nature, Published online: 25 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03802-1 COP30 negotiated efforts to protect forests and ramp up financial packages for climate action, but with one glaring omission: a road map to cut fossil fuels.

title: ‘Anti-woke’ policies blamed for falling attendance at some US conferences
summary:
Nature, Published online: 25 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03869-w

Scientific meetings that support Black, Latino and Indigenous researchers are grappling with funding cuts and other restrictions.
body: Nature, Published online: 25 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03869-w Scientific meetings that support Black, Latino and Indigenous researchers are grappling with funding cuts and other restrictions.

title: ماذا قال توم كروز عند تسلمة أول أوسكار في مسيرته الفنية؟
summary: أشاد النجم الأميركي توم كروز بتأثير السينما وقدرتها على تغيير حياة الناس، وذلك خلال تسلمه جائزة أوسكار فخرية في حفل نظمته أكاديمية فنون وعلوم الصور المتحركة في لوس أنجلوس، حيث احتفت هوليوود بمسيرته الممتدة لأكثر من 45 عاماً وبإسهاماته في صناعة السينما.
